::: {#main-content .container role="main"}
::: {#tips-on-handling-files .section}
[10.12. ]{.section-number}üë©‚Äçüíª Tips on Handling Files[¬∂](#tips-on-handling-files "Permalink to this heading"){.headerlink}
=========================================================================================================================

When working with files, there are a few things to keep in mind. When
naming files, it's best to not include spaces. While most operating
systems can handle files with spaces in their names, not all can.

Additionally, suffixes in files names, for example the .txt in
`FileNameExample.txt`{.docutils .literal .notranslate}, are not magic.
Instead, these suffixes are a convention. For some operating systems the
suffixes have no special significance, and only have meaning when used
in a program. Other operating systems infer information from the
suffixes - for example, `.EXE`{.docutils .literal .notranslate} is a
suffix that means a file is executable.

It's a good idea to follow the conventions. If a file contains CSV
formatted data, name it with the extension `.csv`{.docutils .literal
.notranslate}, not `.txt`{.docutils .literal .notranslate}. A Python
program will be able to read it either way, but if you follow the
convention you will help other people guess what's in the file. And you
will also help the computer's operating system to guess what application
program it should open when you double-click on the file.
:::

::: {style="width: 100%"}
